issues.title: Overall design
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Please find attached some quick comments/inputs about the draft. I embedded some comments directly in the file, with items that I think are easy to fix: use identities rather than enumeration, 64 instead of 32, gauge, etc.

Now for the design, I’m not comfortable to graft the energy optimization directly into the inventory. I suggest to split the design into two parts: energy saving capabilities that can be stored in an inventory and another set of features to tweak those while taking into account topology matters

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: See also #27

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
The path should be changed into 
/ni:network-elements/ni:network-element/ni:components/ni:component/ni:component-id
See snippet in  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ivy-network-inventory-yang/
+--rw components
         +--rw component* [component-id]
           +--rw component-id            string
           +--rw uuid?                   yang:uuid
Can you help fix this in the yang module code.

The description of some nodes mentions "alarm" but without elaborating how these alarms are generated/identified/etc.

I suggest we simply point to RFC 8632  to leverage the alarm framework.

issues.title: Differentiation of inventory data vs monitoring data
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
In my view, the yang model augmenting the inventory should contain only "static" information, That is, the capabilities of the device or the components to save energy, For example,  the part of +--rw energy-saving-modes {energy-saving}? is clear resides in the inventory.

However, the metrics (raw or cooked in some form of KPI), should go to a different model. The base structure of nodes could be similar, but I expect quite a different usage.

comments.author: williamchern
comments.body: Hi, Oscar, as discussed with Qinwu, it is the goal to keep only static information in the inventory, while other metrics goes to other models. Could you please give a more concrete example here, thanks.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> However, the metrics (raw or cooked in some form of KPI), should go to a different model. The base structure of nodes could be similar, but I expect quite a different usage.

Currently those are sperate in the module: e.g., augment "/ni:network-elements/ni:network-element" vs. augment "/nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node"

I guess your comment is to keep only augments to ni in one module and nw augments in a separate module.

that's would be cleaner and easy to do.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Please see #27 for a proposal to split the module into three main areas:
* common
* ntw augmentation
* ni augmentation

I'm not sure yet how/where to put the component container

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: The proposed split make sense to me, the only comment I have is you remove Energy efficiency ratio from energy-consumption-data grouping, which is also a metric or dyanmic data we need to incorporate in.

issues.title: Power Distribution Units Use Case
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
I would like to add the use case of Power Distribution Units (PDUs) to the document:

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7603 describes the use of PDU 

> ower Distribution Units (PDUs) can have built-in meters for each
   socket and can measure the power supplied to each device in an
   equipment rack.  PDUs typically have remote management capabilities
   that can report and possibly control the power supply of each outlet.

The proposal is to be able to model the relationship between a PDU and a network device. This way, the model can report energy measurements/KPIs from PDU and device, or just from PDU if the device is not reporting. 

In my view, the PDU could be modeled as a device in the inventory. The "relationship", that is the physical "eletrical" connection from PDU to network device could be modeled as a link in a network (e.g. a network of type "electrical" that models cables..)

comments.author: williamchern
comments.body: It's possible that the interconnections between devices for Energy Management is different from the physical connection, could modeling PDU as device and electrical connection as link be the general case here?

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
> I would like to add the use case of Power Distribution Units (PDUs) to the document:
> 
> https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7603 describes the use of PDU
> 
> > ower Distribution Units (PDUs) can have built-in meters for each
> > socket and can measure the power supplied to each device in an
> > equipment rack.  PDUs typically have remote management capabilities
> > that can report and possibly control the power supply of each outlet.
> 
> The proposal is to be able to model the relationship between a PDU and a network device. This way, the model can report energy measurements/KPIs from PDU and device, or just from PDU if the device is not reporting.
> 
> In my view, the PDU could be modeled as a device in the inventory. The "relationship", that is the physical "eletrical" connection from PDU to network device could be modeled as a link in a network (e.g. a network of type "electrical" that models cables..)

Can we model PDU as component?, the relation between component and device can be modelled under network model extension.

issues.title: Distributed control and energy saving optimization
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body: In addition to Centralized assessing and controling the energy consumption of links, devices, and devices/components across their networks, I am wondering whether we should also consider to allow network device self optimization, just like Variable speed air conditioners which allow continuously adjust their cooling output based on the temperature & humidity demands.

issues.title: Comments from Jeffi (Device Model)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> Hi Med,
> 
> Thank you for quick clarification. The configuration data is clear now that it can be used by device model also.
> [Med] Greats. Thanks.
> 
> I have still got further questions on the following state data.
> 
>           +--ro energy-saving
>              +--ro enabled?       boolean
>              +--ro power-state?   identityref
> 
> I assume that these nodes would probably augment ietf-hardware.yang’s /hardware-state/container/.
> Please comment.
> [Med] This can augment directly the component node.
> 
> While a component is admin-state locked (and consequently oper-state is disabled), and enery-saving is also enabled for that component, what would be the power-state?
> [Med] The power-state can take one of the mode values (off-state, sleep-state, etc.).
> Is power-state dependent/independent on admin-state/oper-state?
> Please clarify.
> [Med] Good question. No, it is independent of admin-state/oper-state. Added a note so that we clarify this in the text.
> 
> Thanks a lot.
> 
> Regards,
> Jeffi

> From: [mohamed.boucadair@orange.com](mailto:mohamed.boucadair@orange.com) <[mohamed.boucadair@orange.com](mailto:mohamed.boucadair@orange.com)> 
> Sent: Wednesday, November 20, 2024 7:53 PM
> To: Jeffi Edward Holding (Nokia) <[jeffi_edward.holding@nokia.com](mailto:jeffi_edward.holding@nokia.com)>
> Cc: [draft-cwbgp-green-energy-saving-management@ietf.org](mailto:draft-cwbgp-green-energy-saving-management@ietf.org)
> Subject: RE: YANG Data Model for Energy Saving Management Reg.
> 
> Hi Jeffi,
> 
> FWIW, the latest version of the spec is available at: [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-cwbgp-green-energy-saving-management/](https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdatatracker.ietf.org%2Fdoc%2Fdraft-cwbgp-green-energy-saving-management%2F&data=05%7C02%7Cmohamed.boucadair%40orange.com%7C112f456392a745b960c908dd0a26fa96%7C90c7a20af34b40bfbc48b9253b6f5d20%7C0%7C0%7C638677884748496954%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=ta0mC8jtGwJjTd6msGPILTTYadqBiOLVb9Q8JG3%2FTRk%3D&reserved=0) 
> 
> The nodes that you listed below are applicable actually at both the network and device levels. This is why we define them in a common model, ietf-energy-saving-common.
> 
> So far, that grouping is reused at both the network and inventory models. The inventory model reflects the actual capabilities of NEs. We do expect that the same structure can be used by a device model to tweak the saving modes.
> 
> We are pushing to have the same structure at both network/device level to ease mapping and ensure lossless mapping when it comes to touching NEs.
> 
> Hope this clarifies your concern.
> 
> Please let me know if you think that adding some words to spec is needed.
> 
> Thank you.
> 
> Cheers,
> Med
> 
> De : Jeffi Edward Holding (Nokia) <[jeffi_edward.holding@nokia.com](mailto:jeffi_edward.holding@nokia.com)> 
> Envoyé : mercredi 20 novembre 2024 11:42
> À : BOUCADAIR Mohamed INNOV/NET <[mohamed.boucadair@orange.com](mailto:mohamed.boucadair@orange.com)>
> Objet : YANG Data Model for Energy Saving Management Reg.
> 
> Hi Mohamed,
> 
> I was looking at the IETF draft proposed by you for energy saving.
> [draft-cwbgp-ivy-energy-saving-management-01 - A YANG Data Model for Energy Saving Management](https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdatatracker.ietf.org%2Fdoc%2Fdraft-cwbgp-ivy-energy-saving-management%2F01%2F&data=05%7C02%7Cmohamed.boucadair%40orange.com%7C112f456392a745b960c908dd0a26fa96%7C90c7a20af34b40bfbc48b9253b6f5d20%7C0%7C0%7C638677884748520482%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=hw%2B9WhDc3h6BeIMINWLdnbtyTB1UX3dY2JarvipIagc%3D&reserved=0)
> 
> The power saving modes, methods & state defined in the draft are very clear.
> But I still could not get if this model is applicable for network elements (NE) or network controllers (NC).
> I understand that the base modules on which the energy saving module augments are applicable only for NC (ietf-network & ietf-network-inventory).
> 
>           +--rw energy-saving-modes
>              +--rw energy-saving-mode* [mode]
>                 +--rw mode                    identityref
>                 +--rw energy-saving-method*   identityref
> 
> However, looking at the above configuration, I assume that energy saving modes and methods are configured to the NE.
> If then, the above part should be part of NE’s YANG model?
> 
> Please clarify which one implements this YANG model, the NE or the NC?
> 
> Thanks and Regards,
> Jeffi
>

pulls.title: Change module structure and YANG module source code in two different files
pulls.author: billwuqin
pulls.body: These changes are used to address your comments raised in the issue ticket, the main change includes moving dynamic data out of network inventory model extension.

comments.body:
I suggest we also add the following under a node to control it

       +--rw energy-saving-modes
          +--rw energy-saving-mode* [mode]
             +--rw mode       identityref
             +--rw methods
                +--rw method* [method-name]
                   +--rw method-name    identityref

I suggest that all the following be "ro" as this is part of the inventory

      +--rw energy-saving-modes
          +--rw energy-saving-mode* [mode]
             +--rw mode       identityref
             +--rw methods
                +--rw method* [method-name]
                   +--rw method-name    identityref
Why do we need those to be "rw" in the invenrory?
yes, all of those can be read only, especially dynamic data, but energy saving mode, maybe we should still allow "rw", allow the clients control the energy daving mode they can select.
Okay
Sounds reasonable to me.

> yes, all of those can be read only, especially dynamic data, but energy saving mode, maybe we should still allow "rw", allow the clients control the energy daving mode they can select.

The control should not be at the inventory level, but the network level.

So the node level is also readonly, like this:
  augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node:
    +--ro energy-power-consumption
    |  +--ro total-energy-consumption?   yang:gauge64
    |  +--ro saved-energy?               yang:gauge64
    |  +--ro eer?                        decimal64
    +--ro energy-saving-modes
       +--ro energy-saving-mode* [mode]
          +--ro mode       identityref
          +--ro methods
             +--ro method* [method-name]
                +--ro method-name    identityref
We can leave relevant data nodes as rw in nw:node, I guess.
This is not generally recommended for reusable groupings. Let's delete this statement here and refine under the level where the grouping is resued.

Since energy-saving-modes have been used in two different place, one is set as rw, the other place is set as ro, I am wondering whether we can define one grouping, reuses in two places, it looks hard. I am a little bit struggling about this.
Alternatively we don't define grouping, Just define energy saving modes container  in two places, but it seems clumsy.
Yes, we can. Just remove config false from the grouping and refine it when called as appropriate
can you give an example on how to refine?
Yes, that is what I am looking for.
I have fixed reusable grouping issue, the idea is to remove top level container from grouping, define such top level container at the place where the grouping is used and refine it with ro or rw.
Works as well. Thanks

I think we should use "are" instead of 'is' since 'components' are plural.

As currently written, the identity applies only to a device while I think we should not have that restriction to cover devices, entities, components, etc.  The full description is to be updated, I'm afraid. Thanks.
OK, I agree with your proposed change, just point out small nit. It is okay now, I can accept your commit suggestion.
